snippet: Scientists said Wednesday they had reached the waters of a lake that has been sealed off for millions of years.
abstract: Russian scientists have reached a freshwater lake the size of Lake Ontario after spending a decade drilling through more than two miles of solid ice; Lake Vostok, named after the Russian research station above it, is the largest of more than 280 lakes under the miles-thick ice that covers most of the Antarctic continent, and the first one to have a drill bit break through to liquid water from the ice that has kept it sealed off from light and air for somewhere between 15 million and 34 million years.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and JAMES GORMAN
byline.contributor: David M. Herszenhorn reported from Moscow, and James Gorman from New York.

lead_paragraph: Scientists said Wednesday they had reached the waters of a lake that has been sealed off for millions of years.

headline.seo: Drilling Reaches Lake Vostok, Long Trapped Under Antarctic Ice Sheet
headline.main: Russian Scientists Bore Into Ancient Antarctic Lake
headline.print_headline: Lake Trapped Under Ice Is Reached in Antarctica
